title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
Hello everybody :-)

I'm currently working on a MBP (820-01987) with some corrosion around C6406 with pulsing PP3V3_G3H.
It is taking 20V and pulsing 15mA to 22mA.

I don't see any obvios liquid damage on U7650, but I think this could cause the pulsing PP3V3_G3H? It's pretty close to C6406 and could be damaged too?

I am a bit cautious since it is a very new device - so I prefer to ask here first :) 
Best regars

Lucas

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message: Which schematic used in the repair process?

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message: I have the correct schematic - just missing boardview. But there is a illustration of the components in the schematic.

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
[ATTACH type="full"]59643[/ATTACH]
That's how  U7650  looks like.


[ATTACH type="full"]59644[/ATTACH]
Some cororsion on  C6406 




[ATTACH type="full"]59645[/ATTACH]
And some corrosion on C6405

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:

Uploaded it [URL='https://drive.google.com/file/d/15Fgi3ox0FtfMe4085_nG4Hb74Iy9SdEr/view?usp=sharing']here[/URL]

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
That seems to be 00840, already have it.
You said to have 01987 board...

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
My bad! Uploaded the wrong file, sorry!

[URL='https://drive.google.com/file/d/1kiQQnL9692q0Ba3yeV8qjtJNxWOpm-9A/view']HERE[/URL] is the correct one!

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
Steady 20V at USB input?

Check for short on all big coils.
Be sure all solders and traces around U7650 are good.

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
Yes I'm getting steady 20V at USB input (according to my USB-C amp-meter).

Resistance to Ground on the big coils:
L7270: 4.2 Ω,
L7210: 0.6 Ω, 
L7220: 0.6 Ω,
L7410: 0.8 Ω 
L7420: 0.8 Ω,
L7702: 41.5 Ω,
L8102: 130.5 Ω,
L8100: 0.295 kΩ,
L7030: 365 kΩ,
L7690: 1.9 kΩ,
L7670: 23 Ω,
L8410: 1.11 MΩ,

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
"L7210: 0.6 Ω, 
L7220: 0.6 Ω,
L7410: 0.8 Ω 
L7420: 0.8 Ω"
Looks like shorted CPU.
To be sure, lift all these coil one side and see where the shorts remain.

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
The shorts remain on the CPU (PPVCC/GT) side (pin 2) on all of the 4 coils.
Just injected 1.5V on pin 2 of coil L7210 - the CPU took 3 apms, getting warm but not as hot (especially not locally hot) like the other CPU shorts occured on other boards i had for repair in the last months.

I'm still struggling in rating if a resistance of the CPU core is good or not(if it's not 0 or 0.1 Ω :D)

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
The resistance should be bit higher than 1 ohm.
If you have 0.6 ohm, multimeter leads have 0.3 ohm probably.
So CPU itself remains with 0.3 ohm...

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message:
Hmm okay :-( Maybe just don't want to admit that it's another dead CPU :D That was the diagnosis of my last 5 boards.
Sould the pulsing of the PP3V3_G3H stop with removed coils?

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message: I just measured the resistance of the CPU a friends Macbook Pro from 2019. Odlly he had nearly the same CPU resistance (0.9 Ω and 0.8 Ω) on the coils. So maybe there is still some hope for the MBP?

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message: As a reminder resistance to ground must be measured when board/CPU is dead cold and all power drained from it.

title: 820-01987 - pulsing PP3V3_G3H
message: That's what I did :-) Battery disconnected, board was completely cold, left the probes very long for the measurement to be sure it is completely discharged :-)
